1.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Foster Farms Dairy, Inc. dba Humboldt Creamery (FFD/HC) is committed to operating this facility in a manner that is safe for its workers, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, FFD/HC has established a system to help ensure safe operations of the regulated processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at FFD/HC's Fernbridge Facility.  FFD/HC's RMP complies with the requirements of California Accidental Release Program (Cal ARP), OSHA PSM standards, and the EPA RMP Rule.

FFD/HC's RMP consists of three elements:

1.  A hazard assessment to help understand the potential on- and off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases, and accidents that have occurred during the past five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP Rule.

2.  A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate the processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance.

3.  An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of the regulated substance from the covered process.

Information further describing these elements is provided in this Risk Management Plan (RMPlan), and FFD/HC's Ammonia Refrigeration System Procedures Manual.  FFD/HC's Fernbridge Facility, the ammonia processes, equipment, systems, and controls are designed, and constructed to current codes, which reduces the likelihood of an accidental release.  Industry and government standards are closely adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the process equipment and their structures.  

The safety program at FFD/HC's Fernbridge Facility consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP Rule.  This RMPlan is primarily intended to describe those parts of the safety program that are required by the RMP Rule.

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

FFD/HC is committed t

o safety, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  FFD/HC implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances, which include; training key employees to respond appropriately to an accidental release; coordination and training with the Eel River Valley Fire Authority and Eureka Hazardous Materials Response Team (HMRT); coordination with the Humboldt County Division of Environmental Health (HCDEH) to provide CUPA RMP review and facility inspections; establishing in-house inspection and evaluation programs to identify potential hazards; implementing a testing program on critical equipment and piping systems; and coordination with other facilities that have similar ammonia processes, to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damages will be minimal if a release does occur. 

FFD/HC continually monitors the operating set point parameters of its critical equipment using a computer system that can be accessed on-site as well as remotely.  In the event of an accidental release, FFD/HC and the Eel River Valley Fire Authority will assess the situation, and if required they will call other first responders.  FFD/HC and the trained first responders will respond to the release in a manner that will be safe for the responders, the on-site workers, the public, and the environment.  FFD/HC has designated an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and that person will continue to coordinate FFD/HC's response efforts with the first responders, HCDEH, and the local community.  Required changes to emergency contact information will be reported within one (1) month.

In order to effectively implement these policies, FFD/HC established a management system headed by the Operations Manager to oversee safety-related activities.  

1.2  FFD/HC's Regulated Substances Handled and Source Information

As part of this Facility's cooling and refrigeration systems, anhydrous ammonia is stored and utiliz

ed in sufficient quantities to be regulated by the Cal ARP Program, EPA RMP, and OSHA PSM regulations.  The federal threshold quantity is 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, and this facility contains approximately 33,000 pounds.

1.3  Off-site Consequence Analysis (See Section 4, and Appendix A)

FFD/HC performed an off-site consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, which is a regulated substance that could adversely affect the public or the environment.  FFD/HC's OCA consisted of evaluating both worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  

A worst-case release scenario is unlikely to occur; however, FFD/HC's alternative release scenarios represent a release that might occur at a facility like FFD/HC's.  The main objective of performing the OCA is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public because of an accidental release (called the endpoint distance). 

When considering the release of a toxic substance, most people at the endpoint distance would be able to walk away from the exposure without any long-term consequences, although some short-term consequences (e.g., strong eye or throat irritation) are likely.  Some people who are particularly susceptible to the substances released could be impacted.

1.4  Mitigation Measures

The Fernbridge Facility has on-site mitigation measures, which include; a visible wind sock; ammonia sensors within the process and storage areas; sensors connected into alarms and warning light systems; operators present 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; a computer system that monitors critical ammonia process equipment, and can be accessed on-site and at remote locations; a newer facility in which much of the ammonia tanks and systems are located inside; venting systems for pressur

e relief and for venting storage areas; an emergency ammonia system dump control and large sump; a facility that has properly secured equipment and piping systems; PPE equipment located at strategic areas within the facility; an experienced maintenance crew; employee training and establishing emergency response procedures; and FFD/HC has outside agencies, contractors, and emergency response teams conduct training and periodic inspections of the facility and processes.  Additionally, FFD/HC has an emergency generator with a 10 second automatic switch over system in case of power outages.

Off-site mitigation measures include; a visible a wind sock; portable hand held ammonia sensor for emergency response situations, and maintenance monitoring; and coordination with the Eel River Valley Fire Authority, Eureka HMRT, and two other local fire departments, so they can respond to emergencies at FFD/HC's Fernbridge Facility in a safe and efficient manner. 

Additionally, the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Compliance Audits (CA), and inspections of this facility and its processes equipment assists in making the regulated systems and response efforts safer.  

1.5  Accidental Release Program and Emergency Planning (See Appendix B)

In September 2006, FFD/HC reviewed and revised the Emergency Response Plan.  Additionally, Section 7.0 of this report includes a specific Emergency Response Program for ammonia.  FFD/HC maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operations of the facility ammonia processes.  These documents address the physical properties of the hazardous substances handled, operating parameters of the systems, and equipment operating procedures for these processes.  FFD/HC ensures that the process safety information is available and communicated to the operators (Operations Procedures, Appendix D of the RMPlan).

Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) document the physical properties of regulated substances handled at the Fernbridge

Facility, including anhydrous ammonia (liquid and gas phases used in the ammonia processes at the facility (Appendix B of the RMPlan).  

The MSDS information available for a regulated substance typically includes:
Â· toxicity information and permissible exposure limits
Â· physical data (e.g., boiling point, melting point, flash point
Â· reactivity and corrosivity data
Â· thermal and chemical stability data
Â· hazards of mixing substances in the process

MSDSs for the hazardous substance handled (anhydrous ammonia) are available so that the operators and employees have easy access to this information.  In addition, MSDSs are provided to the emergency response team for use in helping formulate emergency response plans.

The engineering design documents include the operating parameters and configuration of the equipment in each covered process (See Operations and Maintenance Manuals, list included in Appendix D of the RMPlan).  When important information is not available from the design documents, it is developed through special projects or, in the case of operating parameters, during the process hazards analyses of the process.  

In July of 2010, FFD/HC reviewed its Ammonia Refrigeration System Procedures Manual (Appendix D of the RMPlan).  This document is used to train employees, to perform process hazards analyses (PHAs), and to help maintain the equipment.

1.5.1  Process Hazard Analysis (See Appendix C of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC reviews and periodically updates the PHAs of the covered processes, which helps to identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process.  A team composed of personnel with engineering, process operating experience, and a leader with process hazard analysis experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of the process.  FFD/HC primarily uses a PHA checklist to perform the analysis.  

On March 28, 2006, Oscar Larson & Associates (OLA) prepared a PHA for FFD/HC.  On 9/11/2006, OLA and F

FD/HC's PHA team submitted a written report describing the results of the updated analysis, including a list of recommendations (Appendix I of the RMPlan).  Responsibility to resolve the recommendations was assigned to unit personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the processes will be implemented.

1.5.2  Operating Procedures (Appendix D of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC's Operations Manager, Maintenance Supervisor, and maintenance crew work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed.  The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operation and process upsets.

FFD/HC personnel develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.

1.5.3  Training (See Appendix E of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC provides annual training for its workers to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  Training programs include; the initial and refresher training, an overview of the process, the properties and hazards of ammonia, and a review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.  The maintenance personnel and operators are consulted annually at a safety meeting to evaluate the effectiveness and frequency of the training.  Recommendations from the maintenance personnel and operators are reviewed, and changes to the training program are implemented as appropriate.

1.5.4  Mechanical Integrity (See Appendix F of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The mechanical integrity program includes; a computer system that monitors critical equipment and system operating parameters;

an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails; hour meters on critical equipment and systems; and a quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in each process.

1.5.5  Pre-startup Review (Appendix G of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC performs a safety review of a new or modified regulated process, before the process is placed into service, which helps to ensure that the process has been prepared to operate safely.  A pre-startup review checklist is utilized to ensure that appropriate issues have been addressed.

1.5.6  Management of Change (See Appendix H of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC reviews their management of change program, which evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without completing a full management of change program.  All other changes must be confirmed through the full management of change program to help ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

1.5.7  Compliance Audit (Appendix I of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC's Compliance Audit (CA) covers the processes to be certain that the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations.  On March 28, 2006, FFD/HC's consultant OLA conducted an updated CA by assembling an audit team that included personnel knowledgeable in the RMP/PSM Standards Rule and in the ammonia process at this facility.  OLA and FFD/HC's team evaluated whether the prevention program satisfies the requirement of the RMP Rule, and whe

ther the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the CA were documented in a report issued on 9/11/2006, recommendations were made, and appropriate enhancements will be evaluated and implemented, if feasible.

1.5.8  Incident Investigation (Appendix J of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented.  FFD/HC provides training to its employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation.  If required, FFD/HC's investigation team will assemble, and an investigation will be initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the investigation will be documented, recommendations will be evaluated, and appropriate process enhancements will be implemented.  No incidents were reported; therefore, no investigations were necessary.  Information on reportable chemical accidents will be added to the RMPlan within six (6) months of the date of the accident. 

1.5.9  Employee Participation (See Appendix K of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC reviews its employee participation program for the covered process, which helps ensure that the safety concerns of the workers are addressed.  FFD/HC encourages active participation of its personnel in implementing its prevention program activities.  Employees are consulted and informed about specific aspects of the RMP, including PHAs and operating procedures.

1.5.10  Hot Work Permits (Appendix L of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC reviews its hot work permit program to control spark or flame producing activities that could results in fires or explosions in covered process areas of the facility.  OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) are discussed, and a hot work permit form is included to comply with these requirements.  Personnel who are to perform hot work are required to utilize the hot work permit pr

ocedures.  The maintenance supervisor reviews the proposed hot work before work can begin.  Training in the use of utilizing the hot work checklist is included in the safe work practices orientation.

1.5.11  Contractors (See Appendix L of the RMPlan).  

FFD/HC has established a program to help ensure that contractor activities within the facility ammonia process areas are performed in a safe manner.  FFD/HC reviews the safety record of contractors that work on or around the process areas to help ensure that reputable contractors are hired to safely perform the desired job tasks.  FFD/HC explains to the contractor supervisor(s) the hazards of the process where their employees will be working, safe work practices, and emergency response procedures. The contractor supervisors are required to have trained personnel work in and around the ammonia process areas.

1.6  Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

In addition to the required prevention program elements, FFD/HC has implemented safety features specific to the Fernbridge Facility ammonia process areas.  The following paragraphs describe some of these safety features:

The facility was modernized in the 1990s, and meets the requirements necessary for operating in a safe manner.  In February of 1986, Northern Geotechnical Incorporated (NGI) completed a Geotechnical Report for the proposed additions to the Fernbridge Facility, and in June of 1993 SHN Consulting Engineers & Geologists, Inc. (SHN) completed a Geotechnical Investigation and Report for building and tank additions.  SHN also conducted piling installation inspection.  These reports were utilized to provide foundation design criteria during the construction of the other additions.  Additionally, Winzler & Kelly Consulting Engineers (W&K) provided engineering design, drawings, and specifications for specific additions.

All process tanks, piping systems, and supports have been designed and installed to meet the seismic requirements, which were in effect during

the design and construction of each process area.  The surrounding structures were also seismically designed.  Flex connectors are used at locations where excessive movement can occur between the tank and the secured piping.  Process container areas and processing piping system are inspected to ensure that they are safe from large objects falling and damaging the container or systems.  

PermaCold Engineering, Inc. (PermaCold), [(800) 455-8585] provides engineering designs, drawings, specifications, and operation manuals for specific ammonia process equipment.  Their trained personnel have the necessary experience in designing and installing systems that meet the applicable codes.  PermaCold conducts testing on the ammonia process equipment, piping, and ammonia sensors.  PermaCold also provides training for FFD/HC personnel that work on or around the ammonia processes.     

Process Cooling [(408) 996-0595], provides piping and control system designs, and operational procedures for specific ammonia processes.  They have the necessary experience in designing systems that meet the applicable codes.  Additionally, Process Cooling has a computer link to the FFD/HC microprocessor (computer), and can monitor the systems operational problems from its remote location.

Ammonia process containers and systems are located inside a fireproof structure, as is most of the ammonia pressure vessels and associated equipment, piping, and valves.  FFD/HC's critical ammonia equipment and systems are monitored by a microprocessor, and will alert operating personnel when systems are operating outside set parameters.  

Ammonia sensors and alarms are provided in areas containing the ammonia processes.  The area alarm is audible, and also a red light is energized to warn workers prior to entering that space.  The facility is staffed 24 hours per day, 7 day per week; and when one of the sensors detect ammonia gas, the on-site personnel will respond as trained.

Hour meters are installed on

the motor of specific process equipment to assist in determining when maintenance and changes are needed.  When equipment is found defective or worn, it is replaced.  FFD/HC has an experienced maintenance crew that keeps the facility and equipment running in a safe and efficient manner.

When transporting ammonia into the facility and filling the tanks, transfer procedures are strictly adhered to. Only trained employee will complete the transfer process, and at least one FFD/HC employee is present during the transfer and filling process to assist in the filing process.

1.7  Five-Year Accident History (See Section 5.0 of the RMPlan)

The FFD/HC Fernbridge Facility has reported no accidents, deaths, personal injuries, or property damage in the last five years, with regard to a release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an incident occurs, then an investigation team will be assembled to follow the incident investigation protocol.  The team will suggest improvements to the process and, if appropriate, improvements will be made (See Appendix J of the RMPlan).  Information on reportable ammonia process accidents will be added to the RMPlan within six (6) months of the date of the accident. 
 
1.8  Emergency Response Program (See Section 7.0 and Appendix B fo the RMPlan)

SHN and FFD/HC have reviewed and revised the written emergency response program, which will assist FFD/HC's trained personnel and their emergency responders to safely respond to an accidental releas of anhydrous ammonia.  FFD/HC's emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations (e.g., the OSHA regulations 29 CFR 1910.39(a) and has been communicated to the local emergency response team.  FFD/HC maintains a regular dialogue with its emergency response teams.  

On April 24, 2005, FFD/HC completed emergency joint response training with the Loleta Fire Department and two other local fire departments (Eel River Valley Fire Authority) and Eureka HMRT, which are trained first responders
